content: The Act is titled the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act titled "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" provides definitions for key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, foreign air carrier, intelligence community, and secured area. The Act defines key terms such as intelligence community, secured area, Security Identification Display Area, and sterile area. The Act defines key terms related to security measures in different areas, including intelligence community, secured area, Security Identification Display Area, and sterile area. Additionally, Section 3 focuses on conducting a cost and feasibility study. The Administrator, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, must submit a cost and feasibility study to congressional committees and the Comptroller General regarding the impact of implementing specific security measures at various airports. These measures include secure doors with card/pin or biometric entry, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, and X-ray screening technology. The study required under subsection (a) will include information on employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening of employees accessing secured areas. This includes costs of establishing entry and exit points and comparing costs and effectiveness of security features to the Federal Government and airports. Upon completion, the Comptroller General will assess the study. The study will compare costs and effectiveness of security features for employee screening at airports to the Federal Government and aviation community. The Comptroller General will review and assess the quality of the study, reporting the results to relevant committees within 60 days. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. They will also assess credentialing standards to address insider threats to aviation security. A report will be submitted to congressional committees after the assessment is completed. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for SIDA applications to strengthen security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, screening notices will be issued to inform applicants about credential requirements for access to the Security Identification Display Area. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for SIDA applications to strengthen security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, screening notices will be issued to inform applicants about credential requirements for access to the Security Identification Display Area, including the possibility of being screened at any time. The text chunk "SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS." is about enhancing security measures for airport workers' access. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. The Administrator will also enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats and mitigate them by leveraging resources from the Department of Homeland Security and the intelligence community. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators and air carriers. Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic to enhance security effectiveness. The Administrator will provide testing results to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers, along with recommendations for employee inspections. An annual report on employee inspection operations will be submitted to congressional committees. A centralized national database of individuals will be established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges for security non-compliance. Reporting mechanisms for data submission and access will be determined, and a process for correcting mistaken entries will be implemented within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other relevant entities. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring IT security reviews within 90 days. No additional funds are authorized for these requirements. SEC. 8. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. The requirements of this Act will be carried out using existing authorized amounts.
